articles.title: Victorian parliament passes Australia’s first Indigenous treaty legislation
articles.summary: "Yesterday Victoria signed a Treaty. Today the sun is rising, so I guess it didn't cause the end of the world."
articles.content:
In a historic first, the State Parliament of Victoria has passed Australia’s first formal treaty with Indigenous First Peoples. It follows ten years of work with traditional owners.

First Peoples’ Assembly of Victoria Co-Chair Rueben Berg talked to ABC News Breakfast the next morning abou the historic treaty:

The treaty is part of efforts to close the gap between Indigenous people and the rest of the Australian community.

The legislation establishes three key bodies: Gellung Warla (the First Peoples’ Assembly of Victoria as a permanent representative body), Nyerna Yoorrook Telkuna (a truth-telling body that will also incorporate truth-telling into Australia’s school curriculum), and Nginma Ngainga Wara (an accountability body). Additionally, an infrastructure fund will be created to give First Peoples greater control of the development projects that affect their communities.

Ngarra Murray, elected Co-Chair of the First Peoples’ Assembly of Victoria, explained why a treaty was needed:

Treaty recognises that Aboriginal people are the experts when it comes to our Country, culture and communities — and makes sure we can use our local knowledge to come up with and deliver practical solutions to improve health, education, and housing outcomes for our communities.

The news was greeted warmly by many Aussies. Mastodon user @susan60 joined others who would like to see it extended nationally:

Post by @Susan60@aus.social View on Mastodon

However, not all Australians welcomed the legislation.

Some opponents believe it will be racially divisive and that it goes against the national sentiment expressed in the rejection of the Federal Voice referendum proposal in 2023. The Voice was to be a permanent consultative body written into the Australian Constitution to offer Indigenous citizens more representation in Parliament; however, it was rejected after more than 60 percent of voters voted no on the referendum.

Margaret Chambers at right-wing thinktank Institute of Public Affairs argued that:

…the treaty will function as a Voice on steroids, creating a separate and parallel parliament based on race. [The treaty] will ensure that our democracy is transformed into a two-tier system based solely on ancestry.

Conservative parties opposed the treaty at both the State and Federal levels.

The conservative rural-based National Party and some of their Liberal Party allies doubled down on their earlier opposition to The Voice. Nationals Senate Leader Bridget McKenzie called Victoria’s treaty legislation “appalling”, while Liberal Victorian MP David Davis suggested that it would bring the state to a standstill.”

Victorian Liberal leader Brad Battin was condemned for his promise to repeal the new law if elected to government in 2026. The pro-treaty “Together for Treaty” movement started an online petition calling for Battin to back down as part of its ongoing campaign.

David Anthony’s comment on a SkyNews Facebook welcomed the treaty, which he described as unifying, not divisive.

Great to see Victoria embrace the Treaty. I still lament the loss of the Voice referendum as the perfect opportunity to ‘close the gap’ and make Australia a greater place. But state Treaties will be a huge help in improving the lives of thousands of people. Victoria coming to a standstill? That’s a pretty hysterical assertion made without evidence. Time for unity, not division.

Most of the replies to Anthony’s comment were very negative, as might be expected on the right-leaning SkyNews, which is owned by Rupert Murdoch’s News Corp. Brian Wray’s response reflected many of the anti-treaty views:

I agree it’s time for unity, the rest of your rant is purely delusional. The Australian electorate voted NO. This action by the Allen government is treachery. Nothing less.

Similar arguments took place on several Reddit posts. This was a typical thread.

The official Treaty website emphasises that the new law will in no way: Change the Victorian or Commonwealth Constitution, establish a “third chamber of Parliament” in the legislative chamber or house of Victoria’s Parliament or change tax laws or provide individual financial “reparations.”

The day after the vote, Indigenous person Big T, sounded a note of optimism on BlueSky:

Yesterday Victoria signed a Treaty.Today the sun is rising, so I guess it didn't cause the end of the world. ❤️ — Big T (@big-tony.bsky.social) 2025-10-31T17:58:15.940Z

The full legislation can be read here.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a historic and significant legislative achievement: Victoria passing Australia's first formal Indigenous treaty legislation. This treaty establishes representative, truth-telling, and accountability bodies aimed at empowering Indigenous peoples and improving their social outcomes, which has broad societal impact and symbolizes progress in Indigenous rights and reconciliation. The article provides detailed context about the treaty's provisions and the public response, fulfilling the criteria for inspiring good news.
articles.personality_title: Victoria passes Australia’s first Indigenous treaty law
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Victoria, a state in Australia, has worked for ten years with Indigenous groups to create a treaty. This treaty aims to improve the lives of Indigenous people and recognize their special connection to the land and culture.

**What happened** – In October 2025, Victoria’s Parliament passed the first formal Indigenous treaty law in Australia. The law creates three main groups: one to represent Indigenous people permanently, one to share honest stories about history and include them in schools, and one to make sure promises are kept. It also sets up a fund to help Indigenous communities control projects that affect them.

**Impact** – This treaty is unique because it officially recognizes Indigenous people as experts in their own culture and land. It aims to help solve problems like health, education, and housing by using Indigenous knowledge. Many Australians welcomed this step, seeing it as a way to bring positive change. However, some people worry it might divide the country or create special rules based on race.

**What's next step** – The treaty will now start to work through the new groups and fund, helping Indigenous communities have a stronger voice in decisions that affect them. Some political leaders want to stop the treaty in future elections, but supporters are campaigning to protect it. This law could inspire other parts of Australia to create similar agreements.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Victoria’s new Indigenous treaty law creates official bodies to empower Indigenous people and aims to improve their communities by recognizing their knowledge and rights.
articles.personality_title_fr: Victoria adopte la première loi australienne sur le traité avec les peuples autochtones
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Victoria, un état d'Australie, a travaillé pendant dix ans avec les peuples autochtones pour créer un traité. Ce traité vise à améliorer la vie des peuples autochtones et à reconnaître leur lien particulier avec la terre et la culture.

**Ce qui s'est passé** – En octobre 2025, le Parlement de Victoria a adopté la première loi formelle sur le traité autochtone en Australie. La loi crée trois groupes principaux : un pour représenter les autochtones de façon permanente, un pour raconter honnêtement l'histoire et l'inclure dans les écoles, et un pour s'assurer que les promesses sont tenues. Elle met également en place un fonds pour aider les communautés autochtones à contrôler les projets qui les concernent.

**Impact** – Ce traité est unique car il reconnaît officiellement les autochtones comme experts de leur propre culture et territoire. Il vise à résoudre des problèmes comme la santé, l'éducation et le logement en utilisant leurs connaissances. Beaucoup d'Australiens ont accueilli cette avancée positivement, tandis que certains craignent une division du pays ou des règles spéciales selon la race.

**Prochaine étape** – Le traité va maintenant fonctionner à travers les nouveaux groupes et le fonds, permettant aux communautés autochtones d'avoir une voix plus forte dans les décisions. Certains dirigeants politiques veulent l'arrêter lors des prochaines élections, mais ses partisans mènent des campagnes pour le protéger. Cette loi pourrait inspirer d'autres régions d'Australie à créer des accords similaires.

**Résumé en une phrase** – La nouvelle loi sur le traité autochtone de Victoria crée des organismes officiels pour donner plus de pouvoir aux autochtones et améliorer leurs communautés en reconnaissant leurs connaissances et droits.

articles.title: Gazans continue heading home as ‘fragile ceasefire’ holds
articles.summary: A month into the ceasefire in Gaza, families continue to slowly head back to their former homes and communities wherever access is allowed, the UN agency that assists Palestine refugees, UNRWA, said on Monday.
articles.content:
Staff remain on the ground providing lifesaving services, and some 100 UNRWA shelters are housing more than 75,000 displaced people, according to a tweet.

Following two years of deadly conflict, a “catch-up” campaign to immunise some 44,000 children under the age of three against measles, mumps and other illnesses kicked off on Sunday. They will also be screened for malnutrition.

Tweet URL

Khawla, a mother-of-three from Beit Lahia in the north, told the UN that she arrived at a vaccination point in the Nussirat area on foot “just to get my children vaccinated and to make sure my daughter stays healthy too.” UN access critical UN aid coordination office OCHA added that “across Gaza, partners supported by the Occupied Palestinian Territory Humanitarian Fund are helping families replant fields, learn in safety, access protection services and more” and “these efforts are offering a fragile but vital lifeline.”

In an opinion piece first published in The Guardian, UNRWA Commissioner-General Philippe Lazzarini wrote that the “fragile ceasefire – the first phase of US president Donald Trump’s 20-point plan – offers some respite to an exhausted population.”

He warned, however, that “there is still much to worry about” as “access to shelter, food and clean water remains challenging” as winter fast approaches.

“The UN, including UNRWA, has the expertise and the resources to address critical humanitarian needs effectively and at scale” but “must be allowed to work freely and independently”, he said.

Mr. Lazzarini stressed that “a truly peaceful future requires a genuine investment in a definitive political solution to the Israel-Palestine conflict.”

He added that “justice needs to be delivered, and healing seriously addressed by both Palestinian and Israeli societies.”

Red tape still blocking aid

Meanwhile, efforts to ramp up aid are still being hampered by red tape, ongoing bans on key humanitarian partners, too few border crossings and routes, as well as persistent insecurity, UN Deputy Spokesperson Farhan Haq told journalists in New York.

This past weekend, teams reported shelling and navy fire in different parts of the Strip “though at much lower levels than before the ceasefire.”

In some areas, teams still have to coordinate every movement in advance with the Israeli authorities.

On Sunday, only two out of eight coordination attempts were fully facilitated. Four were impeded on the ground – including one that was delayed for 10 hours.

Despite the challenges, the UN and partners “are seizing every opportunity to expand operations.”

Damaged hospital rehabilitated

Mr. Haq said the Al Kheir Hospital in Khan Younis resumed operations last week after being forced out of service following attacks in February 2024.

The World Health Organization (WHO) supported the rehabilitation by restoring water, sanitation, power and structural systems, and providing essential medical equipment and medicines.

“WHO also set up a new 20-bed nutrition stabilization centre at the hospital to treat children with acute and severe malnutrition. This brings the total across Gaza to seven such centres, with 70 inpatient beds in all,” said Mr. Haq.

Psychosocial support, winter clothing and water

Between Wednesday and Friday, humanitarian partners reached 1,500 children and 500 caregivers in southern Gaza with mental health and psychosocial support.

Nearly 40,000 winter clothing kits and pairs of shoes have been distributed to children under 10.

Around 50,000 blankets were delivered between Wednesday and Saturday to hospitals and other sites.

Water trucking continues across 2,000 locations in Gaza, restoring access to safe water.

Partners have also distributed 15,000 hygiene kits and repaired a key water line in Gaza City’s Az Zaytoun neighbourhood, restoring part of the domestic supply.

West Bank ‘lifeline’

UNRWA also “remains a lifeline” in the occupied West Bank, including East Jerusalem, where an Israeli military operation in the north, launched at the beginning of the year, has resulted in displacement and destruction.

Tweet URL

At the same time, settler violence has been escalating amid a shrinking humanitarian space.

The Director of UNRWA Affairs in the West Bank, Roland Friedrich, said the agency has over 4,600 staff there, making it the second biggest service provider and employer after the Palestinian Authority.

They support over 930,000 registered refugees across the territory.

Healthcare and education

More than 48,000 children attend 96 UNRWA schools five days a week while 43 health facilities have carried out more than 700,000 medical consultations so far this year.

“We have 270,000 vulnerable Palestinian refugees that benefit from social protection, from cash assistance,” he said in a video posted on social media.

“And we do that in a context, in a humanitarian situation, that is the most severe that the West Bank has seen since 1967.”

Wide-ranging impact

Mr. Friedrich said the “unprecedented escalation of violence” in the north has displaced more than 30,000 people from three refugee camps.

“UNRWA remains a lifeline,” he said.

“We make a distinct contribution, not only to addressing the humanitarian needs of Palestine refugees in the West Bank, and to improving their livelihood and their welfare, but we also make a distinct contribution to stability on the ground and in the region.”

articles.personality_title_fr: Les familles retournent chez elles tandis que l’aide vitale atteint Gaza sous un cessez-le-feu fragile
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – Après deux ans de conflit à Gaza et des tensions persistantes en Cisjordanie, un cessez-le-feu fragile permet aux familles palestiniennes déplacées de revenir lentement chez elles. L’Agence des Nations Unies pour les réfugiés palestiniens (UNRWA) et d’autres partenaires fournissent une aide essentielle aux personnes affectées.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Un mois après le cessez-le-feu, les familles retournent dans leurs communautés lorsque cela est possible. Plus de 75 000 personnes déplacées vivent encore dans des abris UNRWA. Une nouvelle campagne a débuté pour vacciner 44 000 enfants de moins de trois ans contre des maladies comme la rougeole et les oreillons, et pour dépister la malnutrition. Des hôpitaux endommagés, comme l’hôpital Al Kheir à Khan Younis, ont rouvert grâce à l’aide de l’Organisation mondiale de la santé (OMS). Des groupes humanitaires ont aussi distribué des vêtements d’hiver, des couvertures, des kits d’hygiène et restauré l’accès à l’eau potable à Gaza.

**Impact** – Ces efforts apportent des soins de santé, de la sécurité et des besoins de base à des centaines de milliers de réfugiés. La campagne de vaccination protège les jeunes enfants après des années de difficultés. La réouverture des hôpitaux et la restauration de l’eau potable améliorent la vie quotidienne et réduisent les risques sanitaires. Les programmes de soutien psychosocial aident les enfants et leurs aidants à faire face aux traumatismes. En Cisjordanie, l’UNRWA soutient près d’un million de réfugiés par l’éducation, les soins de santé et l’assistance sociale, contribuant à maintenir la stabilité malgré la violence et les déplacements.

**Prochaine étape** – Les groupes humanitaires continueront d’étendre leur aide, malgré les difficultés d’accès et de sécurité. L’ONU appelle à laisser les travailleurs humanitaires agir librement et indépendamment pour répondre aux besoins croissants, surtout avec l’hiver qui approche. Des efforts de paix à long terme sont aussi nécessaires pour régler les causes du conflit et apporter une stabilité durable.

**Message clé en une phrase** – Malgré les difficultés, les retours progressifs et l’aide humanitaire renforcée améliorent la vie de dizaines de milliers de familles palestiniennes déplacées à Gaza et en Cisjordanie.
articles.personality_title_es: Las familias regresan a casa mientras la ayuda vital llega a Gaza bajo un frágil alto el fuego
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Tras dos años de conflicto en Gaza y tensiones continuas en Cisjordania, un alto el fuego frágil ha permitido que familias palestinas desplazadas regresen lentamente a sus hogares. La Agencia de Naciones Unidas para los Refugiados de Palestina (UNRWA) y otros socios están brindando ayuda crucial a los afectados.

**Qué pasó** – Un mes después del alto el fuego, las familias regresan a sus comunidades donde es posible. Más de 75,000 personas desplazadas aún viven en refugios de la UNRWA. Comenzó una campaña para vacunar a 44,000 niños menores de tres años contra enfermedades como el sarampión y las paperas, y para detectar la desnutrición. Hospitales dañados, como el Hospital Al Kheir en Khan Younis, han reabierto con apoyo de la Organización Mundial de la Salud (OMS). Los grupos humanitarios también distribuyeron ropa de invierno, mantas, kits de higiene y restauraron el suministro de agua potable en Gaza.

**Impacto** – Estos esfuerzos brindan atención médica esencial, seguridad y necesidades básicas a cientos de miles de refugiados. La campaña de vacunación protege a los niños pequeños tras años de dificultades. La reapertura de hospitales y la restauración del agua limpia mejoran la vida diaria y reducen riesgos para la salud. Los programas de apoyo psicosocial ayudan a niños y cuidadores a enfrentar el trauma. En Cisjordania, la UNRWA apoya a casi un millón de refugiados con educación, salud y asistencia social, ayudando a mantener la estabilidad a pesar de la violencia y los desplazamientos.

**Próximo paso** – Los grupos humanitarios seguirán ampliando la ayuda, superando desafíos como el acceso limitado y problemas de seguridad. La ONU pide que los trabajadores humanitarios puedan actuar libre y independientemente para cubrir las crecientes necesidades, especialmente con la llegada del invierno. También se necesitan esfuerzos de paz a largo plazo para abordar las causas del conflicto y lograr una estabilidad duradera.

**Mensaje clave en una frase** – A pesar de las dificultades, los retornos lentos y la ayuda humanitaria ampliada están mejorando la vida de decenas de miles de familias palestinas desplazadas en Gaza y Cisjordania.

articles.title: Syria to join US-led coalition to defeat IS group after Trump meeting
articles.summary: Ahmed al-Sharaa, once branded a terrorist by the US, became the first Syrian leader to visit the White House.
articles.content:
Syria to join US-led coalition to defeat IS group after Trump meeting

Watch: 'If you didn't have a rough past, you wouldn't have a chance', says Trump on al-Sharaa

Trump has expressed his support for al-Sharaa, who until recently was designated a terrorist by the US government.

In an interview with Special Report on Fox News, al-Sharaa said the visit was part of a "new era" in which the country would co-operate with the US.

The announcement came as President Donald Trump met Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa at the White House - the first such visit from a Syrian leader in the country's history.

Syria will join the international coalition to combat the Islamic State group, marking a shift in US foreign policy in the Middle East, a senior Trump administration official has confirmed.

Following the meeting, a senior administration official also confirmed that the US Treasury Department, along with the departments of state and commerce, will announce new measures to lift economic restrictions on Syria and provide "compliance clarity for investors".

Syria will now be the 90th country to join the global coalition, which is aimed at eliminating remaining elements of the so-called Islamic State and stemming the flow of foreign militants to the Middle East.

In this photo released by Syrian Presidency press office, President Donald Trump, left, shakes hands with Syria's President Ahmad al-Sharaa, at the White House

As part of the measures, the administration is also issuing an 180-day suspension of the Caesar Act, which since 2019 had sanctioned the former Syrian government.

Speaking to reporters in the Oval Office several hours after the meeting, Trump said that "we want to see Syria become a country that's very successful."

"And I think this leader can do it," he added. "I really do."

Diplomatic relations between Syria and the US have been suspended since 2012, although the US will now allow Syria to re-open its embassy in Washington.

This is the third meeting between the two leaders, following one in May on the sidelines of the Gulf Cooperation Council and a dinner during the UN General Assembly in September.

Al-Sharaa's visit to the White House caps a remarkable re-branding for the former jihadist.

Not long ago, he led a branch of Al-Qaeda - the group behind the 9/11 attacks and many others - before breaking off ties.

Even until this year, he was the leader of Hayat Tahrir al-Sham, an armed Islamist group which the US officially considered a terrorist organisation until four months ago, with a $10m bounty on his head.

The Treasury Department removed al-Sharaa from its "specially designated global terrorist list" just last week.

But since becoming interim Syrian president, al-Sharaa has worked to soften his public image as he tries to rebuild Syria, with foreign support, following 13 years of war.

"He has had a rough past," Trump said on Monday. "And I think, frankly, if you didn't have a rough past, you wouldn't have a chance."

In his interview, al-Sharaa said that he and Trump had not discussed his past, but instead focused on the "present and the future" of Syria in which it was a "geopolitical" and economic partner of Washington.

Al-Sharaa's rule, however, has been marred by killings of members of Syria's Alawite minority, as well as by deadly violence between Sunni Bedouin fighters and Druze militias.

He has vowed to root out members of his security forces that have committed human rights violations.

Trump, for his part, has repeatedly expressed support for al-Sharaa, referring to him as a "young, attractive guy" and a "fighter".

In June, President Trump signed an executive order lifting sanctions against Syria, which the White House said would help support the country's "path to stability and peace".

At the time, the administration said it would monitor the new Syrian government's actions, including "taking steps toward normalising ties with Israel" and addressing "foreign terrorists" and militant groups operating in the country.

The lifting of sanctions and re-establishment of diplomatic relations could foster peace and reconstruction after years of conflict, benefiting many people. While the article acknowledges ongoing human rights concerns, the focus is on cooperation and positive political change.
articles.personality_title: Syria joins US-led coalition to fight ISIS after historic White House visit
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Syria has been involved in a long and difficult conflict for over a decade. Until recently, the US government viewed some Syrian leaders as terrorists and had cut off official relations with the country.

**What happened** – Syrian President Ahmed al-Sharaa visited the White House to meet President Donald Trump. This was the first time a Syrian leader visited the US capital. During the meeting, Syria agreed to join the US-led international coalition aimed at defeating the Islamic State group, also known as ISIS. The US also announced it would ease economic sanctions on Syria and allow the reopening of the Syrian embassy in Washington.

Syria joining the coalition adds a new partner to the fight against ISIS, which could help reduce terrorism in the region. Lifting sanctions and restoring diplomatic ties might support Syria’s rebuilding after years of war, potentially helping ordinary people who have suffered from the conflict.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Syria’s historic cooperation with the US-led coalition and easing of sanctions open a new chapter in efforts to defeat ISIS and rebuild the country.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Syrie rejoint la coalition menée par les États-Unis pour combattre l’EI après une visite historique à la Maison-Blanche
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** – La Syrie est en conflit depuis plus de dix ans. Jusqu’à récemment, les États-Unis considéraient certains dirigeants syriens comme des terroristes et avaient coupé les relations officielles avec le pays.

**Ce qui s’est passé** – Le président syrien Ahmed al-Sharaa a visité la Maison-Blanche pour rencontrer le président Donald Trump. C’était la première visite d’un dirigeant syrien à Washington. Lors de cette rencontre, la Syrie a accepté de rejoindre la coalition internationale dirigée par les États-Unis pour vaincre le groupe État islamique (EI). Les États-Unis ont aussi annoncé un assouplissement des sanctions économiques et la réouverture de l’ambassade syrienne à Washington.

**Impact** – Cet événement marque un grand changement dans la coopération entre les États-Unis et la Syrie. La participation de la Syrie à la coalition pourrait aider à réduire le terrorisme dans la région. La levée des sanctions et la reprise des relations diplomatiques pourraient soutenir la reconstruction de la Syrie après des années de guerre, aidant ainsi la population.

**Étape suivante** – Les États-Unis surveilleront les actions de la Syrie dans le cadre de cette nouvelle coopération. De nouvelles règles guideront les investisseurs intéressés par la Syrie. Les dirigeants continueront probablement à discuter pour améliorer la sécurité et l’économie, avec pour but plus de paix et de stabilité.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La coopération historique de la Syrie avec la coalition américaine et l’assouplissement des sanctions ouvrent un nouveau chapitre dans la lutte contre l’EI et la reconstruction du pays.
articles.personality_title_es: Siria se une a la coalición liderada por EE.UU. para combatir al ISIS tras visita histórica a la Casa Blanca

articles.title: Kos welcomed the adoption of the Law on the Unified Voter Register: An important step
articles.summary: Serbia has fulfilled another item from the non-paper.
articles.content:
BRUSSELS – European Commissioner for Enlargement, Marta Kos, welcomed the adoption of the Law on the Unified Voter Register in the Serbian Assembly and stated that it is “an important step” and that Brussels “looks forward to the implementation of the law in practice.” “For Serbia to progress towards the EU, it needs a framework that ensures free and fair elections and enjoys the trust of citizens,” Kos stated on the X network.

Members of the Serbian Assembly earlier today adopted amendments to the Law on the Unified Voter Register, which provides for the establishment of a commission tasked with the authority to revise the Unified Voter Register. The amendments to the law are the result of parliamentary dialogue aimed at improving electoral conditions, which began in April 2024 based on reports from the OSCE and ODIHR observation missions regarding the elections in Serbia. According to the explanation of the amendments to this law, the dialogue was conducted in accordance with the first priority recommendation of ODIHR from the Final Report on the extraordinary parliamentary elections held on December 17, 2023. (November 7)
articles.reasoning: The adoption of the Law on the Unified Voter Register in Serbia represents a significant step toward ensuring free and fair elections, which is fundamental for democracy and citizen trust. This legislative change has broad societal impact as it improves electoral integrity and aligns with international recommendations, thus supporting human rights and democratic governance.
articles.personality_title: Serbia adopts new law to improve voter registration and election fairness
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** – Serbia has been working to improve its election system after reports from international observers suggested changes were needed. These reports came after elections held in December 2023 and aimed to make elections more trustworthy and fair.

**What happened** – On November 7, 2024, the Serbian Assembly passed amendments to the Law on the Unified Voter Register. This law creates a special commission responsible for updating and checking the voter list to make sure it is accurate and fair. The changes came after talks that started in April 2024, based on recommendations from the OSCE and ODIHR, two organizations that observe elections.

**Impact** – This law is important because it helps make elections in Serbia more free and fair, which means citizens can trust the results more. It also follows advice from international groups, showing Serbia’s commitment to improving democracy and human rights.

**What's next step** – The next step is to put this law into action and see how the new commission works to keep the voter register accurate. This will be watched closely by both Serbian citizens and international observers to ensure elections continue to improve.

**One-sentence takeaway** – Serbia has taken a key step to strengthen democracy by adopting a law that improves how voter lists are managed and monitored.
articles.personality_title_fr: La Serbie adopte une nouvelle loi pour améliorer l'enregistrement des électeurs et l'équité des élections
articles.personality_presentation_fr:

**Ce qui s'est passé** – Le 7 novembre 2024, l'Assemblée serbe a adopté des amendements à la loi sur le Registre unique des électeurs. Cette loi crée une commission spéciale chargée de vérifier et de mettre à jour la liste électorale pour s'assurer qu'elle est juste et précise. Ces changements font suite à des discussions débutées en avril 2024, basées sur les recommandations de l'OSCE et de l'ODIHR, deux organisations qui observent les élections.

**Conclusion en une phrase** – La Serbie a franchi une étape clé pour renforcer la démocratie en adoptant une loi qui améliore la gestion et le contrôle des listes électorales.
articles.personality_title_es: Serbia adopta una nueva ley para mejorar el registro de votantes y la transparencia electoral
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** – Serbia ha estado trabajando para mejorar su sistema electoral después de que observadores internacionales señalaran la necesidad de cambios. Estos informes vienen tras las elecciones de diciembre de 2023 y buscan hacer que las elecciones sean más confiables y justas.

**Qué pasó** – El 7 de noviembre de 2024, la Asamblea de Serbia aprobó enmiendas a la Ley del Registro Unificado de Votantes. Esta ley crea una comisión especial encargada de actualizar y revisar la lista de votantes para asegurar que sea precisa y justa. Los cambios fueron resultado de un diálogo iniciado en abril de 2024, basado en recomendaciones de la OSCE y la ODIHR, dos organizaciones que observan elecciones.

**Impacto** – Esta ley es importante porque ayuda a que las elecciones en Serbia sean más libres y justas, lo que aumenta la confianza de los ciudadanos en los resultados. También sigue las recomendaciones internacionales, mostrando el compromiso de Serbia con la democracia y los derechos humanos.

**Próximo paso** – El siguiente paso es implementar la ley y observar cómo trabaja la nueva comisión para mantener el registro de votantes correcto. Esto será seguido de cerca por ciudadanos serbios y observadores internacionales para asegurar la mejora continua de las elecciones.

**Resumen en una frase** – Serbia ha dado un paso importante para fortalecer la democracia al aprobar una ley que mejora la gestión y supervisión del registro electoral.
